title: Pediatric Evaluation: Carrie Cochlea
chief_complaint: Mother is concerned because my speech and language development seem delayed, and I behave as if I have trouble hearing or understanding.

problem_summary.onset: Congenital or early childhood (history of prematurity/NICU).
problem_summary.course: Stable; developmental delays noted by mother.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Communication delays and behavioral indications of hearing difficulty.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Determine hearing status and cause of speech delays.

history.present_illness: 4-year-old female recently immigrated to the US. Mother reports speech/language delay and behaviors consistent with hearing trouble.
history.otologic_history: Mother vaguely recalls hearing testing in the NICU which she thinks was normal.
history.medical_psych_history: Born very premature with low birth weight; spent a long time in the NICU. Specific developmental history is sketchy.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A tympanograms).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild hearing loss configuration. Air conduction thresholds generally between 20-30 dB HL in low-to-mid frequencies, improving slightly in high frequencies. Bone conduction thresholds match air conduction at tested frequencies (500, 1000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Detection Thresholds (SDT) are 15 dB HL bilaterally, which is better than the pure tone averages (PTA). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) could not be tested.

tests.name: DPOAE
tests.key_findings: Robust distortion product otoacoustic emissions present bilaterally from 1000 to 8000 Hz, with amplitudes well above the noise floor.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: ABR tested at 80 dB nHL using 39/s rate. Waveforms show poor morphology without clear neural waves (I, III, V). The activity present resembles cochlear microphonic or dys-synchronous activity rather than a synchronous neural response.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a discrepancy between peripheral and neural auditory function. The patient demonstrates mild behavioral threshold elevations (PTA ~25-27 dB HL) with better speech detection thresholds (15 dB HL). Objective testing shows normal middle ear function and robust outer hair cell function (normal DPOAEs), but the ABR at high intensity (80 dB nHL) is abnormal/dys-synchronous. This constellation of findings (Present OAEs + Abnormal ABR) is consistent with Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD).
counseling_points: Your daughter's hearing test shows a specific condition called Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD).
This means her inner ear (cochlea) is receiving sound normally, as shown by the OAE test, but the signal is not being sent synchronously along the hearing nerve to the brain.
Because of this, sound may be audible but distorted, making speech understanding difficult, especially in background noise.
We will need to work closely with speech-language pathology and consider a trial with hearing technology (like an FM system or hearing aids) to support her communication development.
notes_for_actor: The child is 4 years old and may not be able to perform word recognition tasks.
The mother is concerned about development but vague on medical history due to the chaotic nature of the NICU stay and immigration.
Emphasize the confusion: 'She hears some things, but ignores others.'
